text: Functions of the Innate Immune System Jenni Bauquier jbauquier@unimelb.edu.au VETS30015 / VETS90121 Intended learning outcomes • Describe the role of the innate immune system • Describe the different types of innate cells found in blood and tissues • Explain how cells of the innate immune system are able to recognise and eliminate pathogens Barriers to infection • Three levels of defense • Physical barriers – e.g. skin, gastric acid, mucous-lined epithelial surfaces • Innate immune system • Adaptive immune system Innate immune systemAdaptive immune systemInnate & adaptive responses Yamauchi & Moroishi, 2019 Innate immune system • Non-specific • Recognises molecules not typically found on vertebrate cells as “foreign” • Also recognises molecules from damaged cells • Rapid • Often constituents of innate immunity are preformed & can be released within minutes by stimulated cells to initiate inflammation • No immunologic memory • Response is the same no matter what the invader • Communicates to adaptive immune system Components of the innate immune system • Granulocytes - contain large preformed granules involved in inflammation • Phagocytic cells - process & present antigen fragments on cell surface • Natural Killer cells - seek & destroy tumours & virus-infected cells • Complement - proteins that enhance immune responses • Cytokines - protein messages provide signals to immune cells Immediate detection of invaders • Receptors for carbohydrates (e.g. mannose) NOT found on vertebrate cells → identifies these as antigens • Macrophages • Receptors for antibodies and complement • Macrophages and neutrophils • Pathogens then engulfed and exposed to a variety of toxic metabolites Lindell, 2012 Antigen recognition – innate immune system • Toll-like receptors • Many cells of the innate immune system • Pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) • Damage-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs) • NOD-like receptors Cells of the immune system mononuclear phagocytes neutrophil eosinophil basophil mast cell platelets other cells Innate Adaptive B cell T cells activated T cell antibodies cytokines complement inflammatory mediators interferons cytokines phagocytes lymphocytes B T T Granulocytes = Polymorphonuclear cells • Neutrophils • Eosinophils • Basophils • Heterophils • Azurophils All have a short half-life & don’t survive long Neutrophils • Predominant circulating phagocytic cell • Granules contain proteolytic enzymes such as myeloperoxidase (critical for oxygen free radical production) • Elastase, proteinase 3, cathepsin G & metalloproteinases • All can be damaging to normal tissue Neutrophils Dog Horse Rabbit (heterophil) Cat Alpaca Sheep Raven Toucan Rabbit Little penguin Iguana Heterophils Python Eosinophils • Eosinophils are much less common & normally only circulate in small numbers (<3% of WCC) • Granules contain enzymes (acid hydrolases, peroxidase) cytotoxic proteins & cytokine mediators • Eosinophils are important when the body is invaded by parasites & during allergy attacks. Granules are released to respond to the parasite & allergens. • Eosinophil granules react with products from basophils, mast cells, lymphocytes eg. eosinophil granules contain histaminase which inactivates histamine • Typically the nucleus is bi-lobed, not multi-lobed as in the neutrophils • Considerable species variation in morphology horse dog cat Alpaca sheep Eosinophils Masked owl Eosinophils Basophils • Normally only present in small numbers in blood (approximately 0.5% of the total leukocytes). • Absent in cats, rats & mice • Basophil granules contain heparin & vasoactive compounds such as histamine • Basophils participate in modulating inflammatory reactions • Involved in immediate hypersensitivities, e.g. allergic reactions to bee stings Monocytes Large (16-25 µm), circulating, phagocytic white blood cell, having a single well-defined nucleus & very fine granulation in the cytoplasm Monocytes constitute usually less than 10% of the circulation leukocytes in dogs, cats & horses The nucleus varies in form & may be kidney shaped, bean shaped, or horseshoe shaped with a deep indentation Macrophages • Monocytes – circulate the body in the blood • Monocytes exit the blood & mature into macrophages • Macrophages are phagocytic cells that process & present antigen to cells of the adaptive immune system • Macrophages are antigen presenting cells (APCs) • APCs are found in the skin (called Langerhan’s cells), lymph nodes, spleen, mucosal epithelia & thymus Macrophages Type of macrophage Location Function Alveolar macrophage Lung alveoli Phagocytosis of small particles, dead cells or bacteria. Initiation and control of immunity to respiratory pathogens Kupffer cells Liver Initiate immune responses and hepatic tissue remodelling. Microglia Central nervous system Elimination of old or dead neurons and control of immunity in the brain. Splenic macrophages (marginal zone, metallophilic and red pulp macrophages) Spleen marginal zone, red and white pulp Elimination of dysfunctional or old red blood cells. https://www.immunology.org/public-information/bitesized-immunology/cells/macrophages Mononuclear Phagocytic cells • Macrophages • Dendritic cells Lung Regions A B C Airway Regions A B Myeloid DC CD11c+ class IIhi CD205+ Myeloid DC CD11c+ class IIhi CD205+ Macrophage CD11c+ class IIlo CD2+ Macrophages & dendritic cells last for long times in tissues & can sequestrate resistant pathogens Dendritic cells • A network of dendritic cells (DC) forms a front line defence on mucosal surfaces • DC recognise, process & present antigen on their cell surface to initiate T cell responses • DC can migrate from mucosal surfaces/ tissues & traffic to the nearby (draining) lymph nodes where they interact with T cells • DC are professional antigen presenting cells nature.com Natural Killer (NK) cell NK cells have cell surface receptors that can recognise foreign cells (tumours & altered cells infected with virus) Activated NK cells respond with non-specific cytotoxic functions. Normal cells of the body are protected from cytotoxicity mediated by NK cells. http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2016-05/waeh-ht052016.php Chemical signals controlling cells of the innate & adaptive immune systems • Lipid derived – released • Prostaglandins, leukotrienes, eicosonoids • Protein derived – secreted • Cytokines Prostaglandin, Leukotrienes, Eicosanoids • Lipid mediators of inflammation & immune regulation derived from arachidonic acid (a normal membrane omega-6 fatty acid) • Released by injured cells • They can also serve as secondary messengers in some events triggered by cytokines Cytokines • Very small proteins that work as messengers between cells • Involved in innate and adaptive immune responses • Typically work over short distances • Autocrine • Paracrine • Some have endocrine effects • Make up a signaling network that controls the immune response Cytokines • MANY different cytokines, produced by many cell types • Single cytokine can act on many different cell types (pleiotropy) • Many cytokines have the same jobs/functions (redundancy/synergy) • Some cytokines antagonise the effects of others • Most are pro-inflammatory, some are anti-inflammatory • Secretion usually transient • Extremely potent Who’s who of cytokines • Meet the families: 1. Tumour necrosis factors 2. Interleukins 3. Chemokines 4. Colony stimulating factors 5. Transforming growth factors 6. Interferons Interferon Action The antiviral state develops within a few hours after IFN stimulation of the cell & lasts for 1-2 days.
